name: ramphastos-toco
definition: The toco toucan is the largest and probably the best known species in the toucan family.
description:
The toco toucan, the largest and best-known toucan species, is at home in South America's tropical forests.

Its oversized, colorful bill has made it one of the world's most popular birds.

Its exact purpose isn't clear, though it is believed to play a role in the courthship ritual and in self-defense.

As a weapon, however, the bill is more show than substance since it is in fact a lightweight honeycomb of keratin, supported by thin rods of bone.

Anyway, the bill is useful as a feeding tool. The birds use them to reach fruit on branches that are too small to support their weight.

The toco toucan feasts on berries, seeds and fruits — especially figs, oranges, and guavas, that cluster in treetops.

The toucan supplements its vegetarian diet by seizing spiders and insects, frogs, small reptiles and small birds.

It often steals the eggs and young of other birds as well.

Toco toucan can weight nearly 600 grams and grow to 65 centimeters long, with their bill accounting for nearly one third of their length.

The toco toucan roosts on a large branch at night, twisting its head so that its bill nestles in the warm feathers on its back.

At first light, the bird rouses and begins searching for food.

The toucan stays among the topmost foliage, and moves by hopping from branch to branch rather than by flapping.

Small groups of toco toucans often indulge in playful antics: the birds jump around each other and stage mock push-and-shove contests with their bills.

Toucans remove dust and sticky seeds by gently nibbling one another’s feathers with the tips of their mandibles.

These toucans nest in tree cavities and usually lay two to four eggs, which both parents take turns incubating.

Young toucans do not have a large bill at birth—it grows as they develop and does not become full size for several months.

It is a common attraction in zoos.

Indigenous peoples regard the bird with a sacred eye; they are traditionally seen as conduits between the worlds of the living and the spirits.

featured.caption:
Fruits develop on slender twigs, too fragile for the bird’s weight, but the toucan can use its long bill to reach out from a sturdy branch.

Although clumsy looking, the bill is dexterous enough to handle small morsels of food with finesse.

trivia.caption: In flight, toco toucan alternates between a burst of rapid flaps with the relatively short, rounded wings, and gliding.

related.definition: The blue-and-yellow macaw is a large South American parrot with mostly blue top parts and light orange underparts, with gradient hues of green on top of its head.
The budgerigar is a long-tailed, seed-eating parrot usually nicknamed the budgie, or in American English, the parakeet.
The red-tailed black cockatoo is a large black cockatoo native to Australia. It is more common in the drier parts of the continent.
